fields.text: {The Nimzovich Defence. It is not that bad if you use it just as a transpositional tool to reach 1 e4 e5 positions - the independent lines, however, are not that reliable for Black, or just downright bad.}
{Instead, 2.d4 is good as well. But 2.Nf3 is logical and easier to handle.} (2.d4 h5)
{Scandi style play - it is very questionable though.}

fields.text: {Now that the bishop has committed to @@SANStart@@b3@@SANEnd@@ @@StartBracket@@no more @@SANStart@@d3@@SANEnd@@ or @@SANStart@@f1@@SANEnd@@ in his future@@EndBracket@@ we happily switch back to normal.}

{I have a hard time believing in moving a pawn one square like 1... @@SANStart@@e6@@SANEnd@@, 1... @@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@, 1... @@SANStart@@g6@@SANEnd@@, etc. The center is there, fight for it !

Don't overdo it with something crazy like 1... @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@ or 1... @@SANStart@@Nf6@@SANEnd@@, of course. Now that I've made some friends, let me give you my list of good black openings against 1. @@SANStart@@e4@@SANEnd@@ to make some more: @@ul@@ @@li@@The Berlin @@li@@The Marshall @@li@@The Petroff @@li@@The Sveshnikov @@li@@The Najdorf @@li@@The Open Spanish@@/ul@@ I'm very curious at what point in the future that list will look completely outdated. If you feel it looks insane already and would like to write a strongly worded letter in defense of the Breyer, the Zaitsev, The Kalashnikov, the Taimanov or the Dragon, please send your complaints to MrDodgyatchessable.com.

Now sometimes, these 'good openings' will not be your best option to play for a win. Fighting for the center, especially with black, will often mean early confrontation there that can lead to either simplification or forced lines making it harder for your opponents to make mistakes. The art of tolerating a slightly worse position after e.g. 1... @@SANStart@@g6@@SANEnd@@ in order to improve our average score in that game has never been a specialty of mine. One could argue that even if playing one of my 'good openings' is not always the mathematically best choice but spending time learning and playing them will build sound chess habits that will make us stronger chess players.

For me, discovering 1... @@SANStart@@e5@@SANEnd@@ and giving up the openings of my youth like the Taimanov and the Modern was eye-opening, life seemed so much easier ! Sold ? Ok, let's memorize some draws ! @@StartBracket@@Kidding - kind of.@@EndBracket@@}

{The Scotch. Instead of the slow battles White seeks in the Spanish or Italian, in the Scotch, White immediately changes the situation in the center, forcing the exchange of his d-pawn for the black e-pawn. That will give White greater center control @@StartBracket@@the pawn on @@SANStart@@e4@@SANEnd@@ versus the pawn on @@SANStart@@d7@@SANEnd@@@@EndBracket@@ , but there is a price to pay: White is no longer the side with a lead in development, as he will move his knight twice in the first four moves. In many ways, that determines the battles to come: White wants to consolidate his better structure/spacial advantage, while Black should try to play dynamically, developing quickly and asking questions. From an opening theory standpoint, the Scotch is far less scary than the Spanish or the Italian. It still pops up in top-level chess, but mostly as a surprise weapon @@StartBracket@@just like Kasparov undusted it in 1990 to spring it on Karpov@@EndBracket@@ . Black is fine, but especially in the @@StartBracket@@critical@@EndBracket@@ lines I will be recommending. The positions are far from typical, the pawn structure, in particular, being nothing that we are used to. Therefore, it pays off to check it out a bit, as play is often quite tactical/move by move, so relying on common sense and pattern recognition is sometimes not as helpful here.}

{This move has been my weapon of choice for a long time now. Black develops the knight and attacks the pawn on @@SANStart@@e4@@SANEnd@@, what could be more natural ?}
(4...Bc5 {@@StartBracket@@is the main alternative, attacking @@SANStart@@d4@@SANEnd@@, not @@SANStart@@e4@@SANEnd@@. As far as I know, it has a good theoretical reputation as well, but I like it less than @@SANStart@@Nf6@@SANEnd@@, also because it gives White quite a choice: @@SANStart@@Nxc6@@SANEnd@@, @@SANStart@@Nb3@@SANEnd@@, and @@SANStart@@Be3@@SANEnd@@ are all mainline moves, leading to very different types of positions.@@EndBracket@@} 5.Be3

Placing it on @@SANStart@@f5@@SANEnd@@ looks very natural and active, connecting it with the square @@SANStart@@e4@@SANEnd@@, a potential outpost for Black. After ~~6...Qxf6## ~~7.Nxd5## we've lost the d-pawn, while 6...@@SANStart@@gxf6@@SANEnd@@ results in an unacceptable pawn structure.

Alright, let's prepare ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ then. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/5n2/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg5 , we could play ~~5...c6## , protecting @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@ reliably. Well, it's possible, but White has the strong reply ~~7.Qf3!## , when ~~7...Bg6## ~~8.Bxf6## ~~Qxf6## ~~9.Qxf6## ~~gxf6## leads to an endgame that is more comfortable for White to play. It turns out that after White's most precise move order, we don't get ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ in under favourable circumstances. We will see that this is not the End of the World, but preventing ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ is an achievement for White. Now, let's compare to the other move orders that are less precise. Let's have a look at move order B. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 White usually continues ~~5.Nc3## , when ~~5...c6!## is the most precise move. We anticipate the pinning move ~~6.Bg5## , when ~~6...h6## ~~7.Bh4## ~~Bf5!## is possible without a problem. In move order A, White exchanges very early on, right on move three. The key difference to the other move orders is that Black has not played @@SANStart@@Nf6@@SANEnd@@ yet, so it's impossible for White to pin the knight with @@SANStart@@Bg5@@SANEnd@@. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 White usually opts for ~~4.Nc3## , when ~~4...c6!## is precise. We cover the @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@-pawn and prepare the move ...@@SANStart@@Bd6@@SANEnd@@. White can't develop their bishop with a @@SANStart@@Bg5@@SANEnd@@ pin - what else to do? After ~~5.Bf4## , we have the simple reply ~~5...Bd6## .

If White plays @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pp3ppp/2p5/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Nf3 , we manage ~~5...Bf5## . The move @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pp3ppp/2p5/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Qc2 stops ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@, but after ~~5...Bd6!## White can't develop their @@SANStart@@c1@@SANEnd@@-bishop at all.

I think I've gotten my point across. Move orders A and B give Black some additional options, usually regarding an early ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ or hindering White's desired development. Whenever different move orders are possible, it is easy to be confused. Therefore I'd like to give you some rules of thumb for this chapter:

1@@EndBracket@@ We need the move ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ to support the @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@-pawn and construct the reliable pawn chain @@SANStart@@b7@@SANEnd@@-@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@-@@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@. Rule of thumb: After White exchanges on @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@, our next move should be ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ right away. Examples are @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 , @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 or the most common @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 . Starting with ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ is not the ONLY way, but it works all the time and is never wrong. If White has already committed to @@SANStart@@Bf4@@SANEnd@@, playing ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ is less urgent. No pin increases the pressure on @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@.

2@@EndBracket@@ The move ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ works well if White has already committed to @@SANStart@@Nf3@@SANEnd@@ and we have ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ played. The latter should almost always be the case @@StartBracket@@rule 1@@EndBracket@@. Examples are @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 5.Nf3 Bf5 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 6.Bg5 h6 7.Bh4 Bf5 @@StartBracket@@inserting ...@@SANStart@@h6@@SANEnd@@ is a small finesse explained later@@EndBracket@@.

A point to remember is that playing ...@@SANStart@@Bf5@@SANEnd@@ before @@SANStart@@Nf3@@SANEnd@@ is on the board is either imprecise - @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 6.e3 Bf5 7.Qf3! , see above - or no particular achievement as @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 5.Bf4 Bf5 allows ~~6.f3## , which is interesting for White.

3@@EndBracket@@ White usually aims for a bishop development to @@SANStart@@g5@@SANEnd@@ but sometimes elects to play @@SANStart@@Bf4@@SANEnd@@ instead. Against all cases of an early @@SANStart@@Bf4@@SANEnd@@, I advise playing @@SANStart@@Bd6@@SANEnd@@, challenging the bishop and offering a trade. White's bishop is well-placed on @@SANStart@@f4@@SANEnd@@, and exchanging it is a good option and always works.

4@@EndBracket@@ If White pins our @@SANStart@@f6@@SANEnd@@-knight, we should attack the bishop with ...@@SANStart@@h6@@SANEnd@@, gaining a useful tempo. This happens in the mainline @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 See Rule 1. ~~6.e3## ~~h6## or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 Again, see Rule1. ~~6.Bg5## ~~h6## .}

{As already stated in the Chapter intro: this early exchange is slightly less precise than White's main move order}
(3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 {. Let's have a closer look at why this is the case.})

{As per Rule 1. We play ...@@SANStart@@c6@@SANEnd@@ right after the trade to support @@SANStart@@d5@@SANEnd@@. Now we will examine three moves for White. After}
(4...c6 5.Nf3 {, we can apply rule 2 and develop our bishop to @@SANStart@@f5@@SANEnd@@. With})
(4...c6 5.Qc2 {, White can stop this idea in its tracks, but} 5...Bd6! {is a good reply. Finally, there is})
(4...c6 5.Bf4 {, which we answer with} 5...Bd6 {, applying Rule 3.})
{Our Rule 2 applies here, so here we go!}

{Black is also fine with other moves. One example is}
(5...Nf6 {, which would transpose to a variation of the current chapter that arises after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 . Still, if we get the opportunity to develop the bishop to @@SANStart@@f5@@SANEnd@@ without any problems, we should go for it.})

fields.text:
{If you have studied the chapter intro, you have seen the famous game M. Bobotsov vs. T.Petrosian @@LinkStart@@https://www.chessable.com/variation/16052800@@LinkEnd@@ , Lugano Olympiad 1968. Petrosian outplayed his opponent in an exemplary fashion, demonstrating the knight's strength on @@SANStart@@d6@@SANEnd@@ later on.

The structure and material distribution on the board is identical to the mentioned game. If you have not studied it yet, I suggest doing it right away. It helps to understand the strategy much better.}

{White may choose to capture on d5 at various moments. In our repertoire framework, there are four possible moments.

A@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5

B@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5

C@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5

D@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 a6 5.cxd5 exd5

Let's examine the differences and how to evaluate each version. I'd like to start with D, as this type of Carlsbad has some specific points due to the early ...a6 move that we have played. This line is not covered in the current chapter but in the dedicated chapter @@LinkStart@@https://www.chessable.com/course/92793/13@@LinkEnd@@ on @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 a6 .

What about the other three versions? Well, the only version considered to be challenging for Black is C, while A and B are considered to be less critical. Let's work out why this is the case. I suggest looking at C first and then comparing. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 we reach the Carlsbad structure. After the exchange on d5, a major issue in the QGD for Black has improved dramatically. Our c8-bishop is not staring at the e6-pawn but now enjoys an open diagonal c8-g4.

We are happy about this change, but now the question is: where to develop the bishop? Placing it on f5 looks very natural and active, connecting it with the square e4, a potential outpost for Black. So let's play ...Bf5, right? The issue is: after White's best move, ~~5.Bg5## , we can't play ~~5...Bf5?## because of ~~6.Bxf6## . After ~~6...Qxf6## ~~7.Nxd5## we've lost the d-pawn, while 6...gxf6 results in an unacceptable pawn structure.

Alright, let's prepare ...Bf5 then. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/5n2/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg5 , we could play ~~5...c6## , protecting d5 reliably. Now White's most common reply is ~~6.e3## , preparing Bd3 next. Can we play ~~6...Bf5## now? Well, it's possible, but White has the strong reply ~~7.Qf3!## , when ~~7...Bg6## ~~8.Bxf6## ~~Qxf6## ~~9.Qxf6## ~~gxf6## leads to an endgame that is more comfortable for White to play. It turns out that after White's most precise move order, we don't get ...Bf5 in under favourable circumstances. We will see that this is not the End of the World, but preventing ...Bf5 is an achievement for White. Now, let's compare to the other move orders that are less precise. Let's have a look at move order B. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 White usually continues ~~5.Nc3## , when ~~5...c6!## is the most precise move. We anticipate the pinning move ~~6.Bg5## , when ~~6...h6## ~~7.Bh4## ~~Bf5!## is possible without a problem. In move order A, White exchanges very early on, right on move three. The key difference to the other move orders is that Black has not played Nf6 yet, so it's impossible for White to pin the knight with Bg5. After @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 White usually opts for ~~4.Nc3## , when ~~4...c6!## is precise. We cover the d5-pawn and prepare the move ...Bd6. White can't develop their bishop with a Bg5 pin - what else to do? After ~~5.Bf4## , we have the simple reply ~~5...Bd6## .

If White plays @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pp3ppp/2p5/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Nf3 , we manage ~~5...Bf5## . The move @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pp3ppp/2p5/3p4/3P4/2N5/PP2PPPP/R1BQKBNR w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Qc2 stops ...Bf5, but after ~~5...Bd6!## White can't develop their c1-bishop at all.

I think I've gotten my point across. Move orders A and B give Black some additional options, usually regarding an early ...Bf5 or hindering White's desired development. Whenever different move orders are possible, it is easy to be confused. Therefore I'd like to give you some rules of thumb for this chapter:

1@@EndBracket@@ We need the move ...c6 to support the d5-pawn and construct the reliable pawn chain b7-c6-d5. Rule of thumb: After White exchanges on d5, our next move should be ...c6 right away. Examples are @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 , @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 or the most common @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 . Starting with ...c6 is not the ONLY way, but it works all the time and is never wrong. If White has already committed to Bf4, playing ...c6 is less urgent. No pin increases the pressure on d5.

2@@EndBracket@@ The move ...Bf5 works well if White has already committed to Nf3 and we have ...c6 played. The latter should almost always be the case @@StartBracket@@rule 1@@EndBracket@@. Examples are @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 5.Nf3 Bf5 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 6.Bg5 h6 7.Bh4 Bf5 @@StartBracket@@inserting ...h6 is a small finesse explained later@@EndBracket@@.

A point to remember is that playing ...Bf5 before Nf3 is on the board is either imprecise - @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 6.e3 Bf5 7.Qf3! , see above - or no particular achievement as @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5 4.Nc3 c6 5.Bf4 Bf5 allows ~~6.f3## , which is interesting for White.

3@@EndBracket@@ White usually aims for a bishop development to g5 but sometimes elects to play Bf4 instead. Against all cases of an early Bf4, I advise playing Bd6, challenging the bishop and offering a trade. White's bishop is well-placed on f4, and exchanging it is a good option and always works.

4@@EndBracket@@ If White pins our f6-knight, we should attack the bishop with ...h6, gaining a useful tempo. This happens in the mainline @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Bg5 c6 See Rule 1. ~~6.e3## ~~h6## or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.cxd5 exd5 5.Nc3 c6 Again, see Rule1. ~~6.Bg5## ~~h6## .}

{As already stated in the Chapter intro: this early exchange is slightly less precise than White's main move order}
(3.Nc3 Nf6 4.cxd5 {. Let's have a closer look at why this is the case.})

{As per Rule 1. We play ...c6 right after the trade to support d5. Now we will examine three moves for White. After}
(4...c6 5.Nf3 {, we can apply rule 2 and develop our bishop to f5. With})
(4...c6 5.Qc2 {, White can stop this idea in its tracks, but} 5...Bd6! {is a good reply. Finally, there is})
(4...c6 5.Bf4 {, which we answer with} 5...Bd6 {, applying Rule 3.})
{Sielecki doesn't cover this poor move that is played a fair amount.}
{Engine says Black is fine. ðŸ’ª}

{This Chapter deals with a branch of the Queen's Gambit, the Catalan opening. What exactly is the Catalan? Whenever White combines the moves d4, c4 and g3 against Black's ...e6/...d5-formation, we reach a Catalan. There are some possible move orders that White may go for. By far the most common one is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 , but we will also examine @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.g3 .

Besides these move orders after 1.d4, there are various ways to reach the Catalan via 1.c4 or 1.Nf3. Against both moves, I recommend a ...e6/...d5-based concept, when a quick g3 and d4 by White may quickly transpose to the Catalan, too. Alright, what is our antidote against the Catalan? Black has a wide choice of reliable lines but, there is no clear picture of what might be best. I recommend building the repertoire based on @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 dxc4 5.Bg2 c5 , so the basic concept is to take the c-pawn and quickly attack White's centre with ...c5. White has alternatives on the way, but they will be met in similar fashion, like @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.g3 dxc4 4.Nf3 c5 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 dxc4 5.Qa4+ Bd7 6.Qxc4 c5 .

We also use this general approach @@StartBracket@@take c4, play ...c5@@EndBracket@@ in the English Opening/Reti: after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.g3 d5 3.Bg2 Nf6 4.Nf3 I recommend playing ~~4...dxc4## ~~5.Qa4+## ~~Bd7## ~~6.Qxc4## ~~c5## . In all these lines, we usually will follow up the move ...c5 with ...Nc6, increasing the pressure on d4.}
{Playing 3.Nf3 is White's best move order to reach a Catalan.}

fields.alt_fail: Be7, Nd7, a6, c5, c6, dxc4

fields.text: {The main starting position of the Catalan. As explained in the notes on move two: I suggest taking the c-pawn after White has committed to the fianchetto.}

{Alright, let's take the pawn. The main point of the capture is not to win and keep a pawn but to accomplish two things. 1@@EndBracket@@ White has played g3, which makes regaining the pawn more difficult. You many compare to e.g. @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 dxc4 , when 4.e3 or 4.e4 prepare the convenient Bxc4. In the Catalan, the bishop belongs to g2, so White needs a different take. As we will see, manoeuvres like Qa4xc4 take time and give Black ideas for counterplay.

2@@EndBracket@@ The second point of 4...dxc4 is to open the scope of our queen and put some pressure on d4. We'll increase the pressure with a quick ...c5.

After 4...dxc4 White's overwhelming main line is 5.Bg2, but we need to examine 5.Qa4+ , too. Against this move, Black has multiple good options.}
{White's main move and certainly the most dangerous one. After the conservative 5.Qa4+, I don't see any challenges for Black.}
{Black has a vast choice in this position. I suggest playing 5...c5, but at a later stage, you have plenty of options to expand your repertoire at this point.}
fields.alt_fail: Bb4+, Be7, Nbd7, Nc6, a6, c6

fields.text:
{White's mainline by a mile. After}
(6.Qa4+ {I suggest} 6...Bd7 7.Qxc4 b5 {, which we examine via the move order @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2pP4/5NP1/PP2PP1P/RNBQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Qa4+ Bd7 6.Qxc4 c5 7.Bg2 b5 . Black has good chances in this line.})

{We develop the knight and increase the pressure on d4. After this logical move, White has three main moves â€“ 7.Qa4, 7.dxc5, and 7. Ne5 â€“ that I will examine. Before we go into details, I'd like to add that the current position may also occur via other move orders that did not start as a Catalan. The most important one is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.Nf3 d5 2.g3 c5 3.Bg2 Nc6 4.d4 Nf6 5.O-O e6 6.c4 dxc4 , which is a key part of our concept against 1.Nf3/2.g3. The chapter on 1.Nf3 provides more detail on the moves that lead to this surprising transformation. A less common way is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.g3 , when ~~3...e6## ~~4.Bg2## ~~c5## ~~5.O-O## ~~Nc6## ~~6.c4## ~~dxc4## again transposes to the current line. I have suggested this move order for White in my Chessable course Keep it Simple: 1.d4 and now will examine Black's perspectives in this interesting variation.}

{By far the best move, covering the knight. Now White's best try is 8.Na3, as I also stated in Keep it Simple 1.d4. We'll also have a look at the harmless 8.Nxc6 and the pawn sacrifice 8.Nxc4, which is more ambitious but ultimately not scary for Black.}

{A very logical move, getting the knight out to capture on c4. White can also play}
(8.Nd2 {with the same idea, when} 8...cxd4 9.Ndxc4 {leads to the same positions.})
{Alright, we have two extra pawns...}

{Well, the second extra pawns didn't stay on the board for very long, but we still have d4. White has compensation for the material loss, seeing that White's pieces are very active. Quite often, this pressure is enough to win back d4. Our job is to neutralize White's activity and use the extra pawn or return it under favourable or at least fair circumstances.}
{White prepares to play Qb3 next, when ...Qc7 is not possible anymore.}

{We need to play the most precise move to address Qb3, which is 10...Rc8. Our idea is to answer Qb3 with ...Nd5, which works best with the rook already on c8. It's helpful to see the difference after}
(10...O-O 11.Qb3 Nd5? {, when} 12.Qxb7 Nxe5 13.Nxe5 {leads to a deadly double attack on our bishop and rook. After 10...Rc8, we'll examine 11.Nxd7 and 11.Qb3. White will win back the pawn in both cases, but we'll equalize without any problems.})
{White starts an immediate operation to regain the pawn.}

{This is a lot safer than}
(11...Nxd7 12.Nd6+ Bxd6 13.Bxd6 {. In this line, White has too much compensation for my taste. It is a playable option if you want to up the stakes. 11...Qxd7 is more reliable but does not offer many winning chances against good play.})
{White removes the c6-knight, the key defender of the d4-pawn.}

{It's useful to remember this move, as it is not so easy to prove equal chances with other moves. Now White can't play}
(13...Qb5! 14.Bxd4?? {, as} 14...Rd8! {creates a deadly pin.})

{We have equal chances here. White's bishop pair looks great, but it is not well organized. {The King's Pawn Opening. White's assertive opening move opens lines for the queen and the king's bishop and fights for control of the d5- and f5-squares. This move is popular at all levels of the game and was the favored opening move of world champion Bobby Fischer who called it 'best by test.' Openings with 1.e4 are thought of as more sharp and attacking than those with 1.d4, but this is an extreme generalization. Both players will have many more opportunities to influence the type of position that appears. With a pawn on e4, White's most common plan is to play d4 on the next move, creating a pawn mass in the center.}

{The acid test to 1.e4. It looks very logical to counter 1.e4 with a solid 1...e5. With 1.e4, White fights for control of the d5- and f5-squares. Likewise with 1...e5, Black does the same thing by gaining control over the d4- and f4-squares. By the way, 1...e5 was my first huge Lifetime Repertoire Chessable course and gives me pleasant memories. Now the roles have been reversed.}

{The Scotch Opening. Kasparov often employed this opening as his â€œsecret weaponâ€ against 1...e5. He mainly used it as an alternative to the Ruy LÃ³pez â€“ the most popular opening with 1.e4 e5 at the top-level. The Scotch Game is characterized by White pushing d2-d4 on his third move, instead of developing the kingâ€™s bishop, as is more common in the Spanish or the Italian. However, there is one question you must ask yourself, and it is why you should choose this opening over a different one. Why play the Scotch Game? Several reasons lead a player to choose an opening over others. One of them is particular taste and preferred style over the board. For instance, a solid and strategic player who prefers slow-paced games might opt for 1.d4. A highly creative and tactical chess player will most certainly feel inclined towards 1.e4. Black does not have the opportunity to shape the character of the game as much as White does since they move first. If you are playing with the Black pieces and face 1.e4, replying symmetrically with 1...e5 is one of the most popular options. If you have the White pieces and decide to start with 1.e4, what to play against 1...e5 is one of the most important decisions you will make. Here is why the Scotch Game may be a good option for you. Whiteâ€™s idea behind playing d2-d4 on move 3 is to achieve harmonious development and take control over the centre. It offers logical and natural development of the pieces and many chances to grab an advantage. The Scotch Opening does not have as much opening theory as the Ruy LÃ³pez or the Italian Game. It is more likely to find unprepared opponents as the Spanish and Italian are more popular. This opening is often neglected by 1...e5 players who believe they will face other openings in the majority of their games.}

{This move is the only one that makes sense in this position. As mentioned in the previous section, Whiteâ€™s idea by playing d2-d4 is to achieve full central control from early on. If Black replies in a passive way and does not take this pawn immediately, White may have the chance to push d4-d5 or play dxe5 and establish great control of the central squares, while also gaining a lot of space. For instance, if Black plays a move like d7-d6 â€“ seemingly supporting the e5-pawn, White can choose between d4-d5 or dxe5 in order to claim an advantage.}

In the Rubinstein, Black usually develops his light squared bishop along the b7/c6-h1 diagonal, either by b6+Bb7 or Bd7-c6. By placing our bishop on f3, we prevent said developing scheme. Of course, the knight now cannot occupy the f3 square but it will be well placed on e2.}

Note that neither Nc6 nor Bd7 are possible &#40the b7 pawn would hang in the latter&#41. On top of that, White has ideas with Nd4-b5-c7/d6, which are not easy for Black to meet.}

{The King's Pawn Opening. White's assertive opening move opens lines for the queen and the king's bishop and fights for control of the d5- and f5-squares. This move is popular at all levels of the game and was the favored opening move of world champion Bobby Fischer who called it 'best by test.' Openings with 1.e4 are thought of as more sharp and attacking than those with 1.d4, but this is an extreme generalization. Both players will have many more opportunities to influence the type of position that appears. With a pawn on e4, White's most common plan is to play d4 on the next move, creating a pawn mass in the center.}

{The acid test to 1.e4. It looks very logical to counter 1.e4 with a solid 1...e5. With 1.e4, White fights for control of the d5- and f5-squares. Likewise with 1...e5, Black does the same thing by gaining control over the d4- and f4-squares. By the way, 1...e5 was my first huge Lifetime Repertoire Chessable course and gives me pleasant memories. Now the roles have been reversed.}

{The Scotch Opening @@StartBracket@@sounds like a cocktail name@@EndBracket@@.

This opening got immense popularity thanks to the efforts of the GOAT Garry Kasparov. He employed it in some of his games against Karpov to change the character play. As they often battled in the territory of Ruy Lopez, Kasparov felt the need to change to pose some problems for Karpov, and later he used it in many of his tournament games quite successfully. The play is quite direct here as White immediately bangs the centre.

One more prominent strong player comes to my mind who played Scotch regularly is Morozevich. Apart from the other two major openings against 1...e5 namely Ruy Lopez and Italian, The scotch definitely had a recent surge as it enters into unexplored areas. It can also act as a nice surprise for your opponent if you are a player who regularly opts for the Ruy Lopez. In any case, it is a nice addition to have in one's repertoire.}
{The only sensible move in this position. Any other move would simply give White free space in the centre.}

{Even though the move 4â€¦Nf6 has been the main line in recent times, the classical 4â€¦Bc5 is still the most played in the Scotch game due to its simplicity in nature.

Players with a classical formation and who do not wish to transpose to the Four Knights Variation or get into the complications of the Mieses Variation will certainly prefer this move, not much concrete theory as well.

This is a sensible move, as Black is developing his Bishop exerting pressure on Whiteâ€™s central Knight on d4 and as well the Bishop on c5 becomes a dangerous piece along the a7-f2 diagonal. After 4â€¦Bc5, it is now White who is faced with a choice of how to deal with the attack on the d4 Knight?

There are three different approaches he can use in this position, 4.Nxc6 4.Be3 and 4.Nb3. I like the latter most as it attacks the c5 Bishop without having to waste a tempo.}

{is one of the fashionable options nowadays. This is perhaps the most logical move, instead of losing a tempo, White wins one by attacking Blackâ€™s bishop and forcing it to retreat. Since Black exerts pressure on our knight on d4 , it looks more to the point in retreating the knight with tempo. For instance, in the old mainline with}
(5.Be3 Qf6 {There is always some added pressure on the d4-knight. Black usually replies by retreating the bishop to b6, as it is the only available square to keep pressuring the center and the f2-pawn.})
{The right bishop retreat compared to others as it maintains pressure on the f2-pawn and the bishop obviously remains more active on b6 than on e7.}

{The mainline which is a acid test for White arising from the classical 4...Bc5 system. With this move, Black immediately keeps an eye on our central pawn and aims for quick development with O-O and Re8.}

What's the point of the capture? There are two, actually: in the best case, we just keep the pawn! This can easily happen if White is careless or doesn't know any theory at all. You'll often meet opponents who never studied the capture seriously and handle it poorly, giving you a simple extra pawn. The secondary objective is to gain time, as White needs to invest moves to get the pawn back.

This approach is similar to our line against the Catalan, which also involves an early ...d5xc4 @@StartBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 dxc4 @@EndBracket@@.

{The Scotch. Instead of the slow battles White seeks in the Spanish or Italian, in the Scotch, White immediately changes the situation in the center, forcing the exchange of his d-pawn for the black e-pawn. That will give White greater center control (the pawn on e4 versus the pawn on d7) , but there is a price to pay: White is no longer the side with a lead in development, as he will move his knight twice in the first four moves. In many ways, that determines the battles to come: White wants to consolidate his better structure/spacial advantage, while Black should try to play dynamically, developing quickly and asking questions.

From an opening theory standpoint, the Scotch is far less scary than the Spanish or the Italian. It still pops up in top-level chess, but mostly as a surprise weapon (just like Kasparov undusted it in 1990 to spring it on Karpov) . Black is fine, especially in the (critical) lines I will be recommending. The positions are far from typical, the pawn structure, in particular, being nothing that we are used to. Therefore, it pays off to check it out a bit, as play is often quite tactical/move by move, so relying on common sense and pattern recognition is sometimes not as helpful here.}

{Not the most logical move in the world. Instead of attacking e5 and preparing short castling, White feels his queen's knight should be brought out first. Of course, no harm is done, he is White and develops a piece, but there are reasons why this move is less popular than 2. Nf3.}
{On Team Black, we believe in kingside castling.}

{The Vienna Game. A line that is taught to many beginners, setting the trap ...exf4 e5! It was a bit of an epidemic in my Hamburg Chess Club in the early 90s, where lots of kids were taught this idea to punish 1...e5. Good thing I was Team 1...g6 -- then 3.f4 is no good! After Black's next move, countering in the center, Black is already on the verge of being slightly better. I believe this position has more raison d'etre with colors reversed, where it can occur via 1.Nf3 f5 2.d3 Nc6 3.e4 e5 4.d4!}
{This center-counter is all you really need to keep in mind.}
{A fairly nonstandard position has arisen early. White has some options here, but none that should instill much fear into our hearts.}
{A somewhat surprising move, provoking d4 so that we can pin the knight with Bb4, also making sure White can no longer go d3 and challenge our knight.}

fields.text: {A solid choice for White. They cover the c-pawn and prepare the kingside development. The e-pawn now obstructs the queen's bishop, so White usually aims for a fianchetto on the queenside. Their usual setup involves bishops on d3 and b2, while the placement of the knight is not yet clear. White may opt for Nc3, putting more pressure on d5, or for Nbd2, which emphasizes control of e5.}

{Playing ...a6 is not the most obvious thing to do first. What's the point of this move? We gain the option of taking the c-pawn and immediately follow with ...b5 for a queenside expansion. This is particularly effective if White decides to develop the f1-bishop when this piece takes two moves to capture c4. A sample variation is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.e3 a6 5.Bd3?! dxc4! 6.Bxc4 b5 , which is very comfortable for Black. We are one tempo up on the Queen's Gambit Accepted mainline @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 dxc4 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.e3 e6 5.Bxc4 a6 , which is already satisfactory for Black. An extra tempo makes a significant difference, as the position opens up quickly.

A knowledgeable opponent will anticipate our idea and avoid this scenario. The way to go for White is an early b2-b3, which makes the capture on c4 unattractive, as White would recapture with the b-pawn, strengthening their central control.

The move b2-b3 is the signal move for us to abandon the idea of capturing on c4. How do we develop the queenside then? I suggest aiming for a development scheme that involves the moves ...Nbd7, ...b6, Bb7 and ...Bd6. This harmonious formation we also use against the line @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.e3 Nf6 / @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.Nf3 d5 2.e3 Nf6 3.c4 e6 , which may often transpose into lines of the current chapter if White opts for a later d2-d4 pawn push.}

{A very natural continuation. the current position after 5.Nc3 may also arise via different move orders, for example @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 a6 5.e3}

{We continue our strategy of waiting for an untimely bishop move. most of the time, White now plays @@StartFEN@@r1bqkb1r/1ppn1ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N1PN2/PP3PPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 2 6@@EndFEN@@ 6.b3 to stop any ...dxc4 plans and prepare Bb2. We'll still have a look at @@StartFEN@@r1bqkb1r/1ppn1ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N1PN2/PP3PPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 2 6@@EndFEN@@ 6.Bd3?! dxc4! and @@StartFEN@@r1bqkb1r/1ppn1ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N1PN2/PP3PPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 2 6@@EndFEN@@ 6.cxd5 exd5 , which leads to a harmless version of the Carlsbad structure.}

{Sielecki doesn't cover this move that the engine doesn't love but it isn't terrible, and it can be hard to handle. I handled it very poorly against Johnny Harbieh in Feb 2024. Masters sometimes play it. It's far down the list of pleb moves.}
{Plebs play 6...c6 more often, but this is the clear engine favorite.}
{Best engine move and played the most. 7...c5 and 7...Nxb6 are also engine approved and keep the game even.}

{I have a hard time believing in moving a pawn one square like 1... e6, 1... c6, 1... g6, etc. The center is there, fight for it !

Don't overdo it with something crazy like 1... d5 or 1... Nf6, of course. Now that I've made some friends, let me give you my list of good black openings against 1. e4 to make some more: @@ul@@ @@li@@The Berlin @@li@@The Marshall @@li@@The Petroff @@li@@The Sveshnikov @@li@@The Najdorf @@li@@The Open Spanish@@/ul@@ I'm very curious at what point in the future that list will look completely outdated. If you feel it looks insane already and would like to write a strongly worded letter in defense of the Breyer, the Zaitsev, The Kalashnikov, the Taimanov or the Dragon, please send your complaints to MrDodgyatchessable.com.

Now sometimes, these 'good openings' will not be your best option to play for a win. Fighting for the center, especially with black, will often mean early confrontation there that can lead to either simplification or forced lines making it harder for your opponents to make mistakes. The art of tolerating a slightly worse position after e.g. 1... g6 in order to improve our average score in that game has never been a specialty of mine. One could argue that even if playing one of my 'good openings' is not always the mathematically best choice but spending time learning and playing them will build sound chess habits that will make us stronger chess players.

For me, discovering 1... e5 and giving up the openings of my youth like the Taimanov and the Modern was eye-opening, life seemed so much easier ! Sold ? Ok, let's memorize some draws ! @@StartBracket@@Kidding - kind of.@@EndBracket@@}

{The Ruy Lopez. Or do we call it the Spanish ? I keep getting confused. No longer the only cool kid on move 3 with} (3.Bc4 {closing in when it comes to popularity, but still the move leading to the richest and most diverse middlegames.

'Mastering the Spanish means mastering chess' as a wise man once said. The truth is White doesnt really want to take on c6 next move. The bishop just goes to an active square keeping the option to take on c6 one day, but mainly White wants to castle and then occupy the center.})

{Calling the bluff, daring White to take on c6. Yup, I'm aware 3... Nf6 aka the Berlin is pretty popular these days. But they don't call it the Borelin for nothing, the endgames or positions after} (3...Nf6 4.O-O Nxe4 5.Re1 {

aren't everybody's cup of tea. I will admit it's a pretty sound opening though. So hard to argue with AlphaZero these days... While the Berlin has become the darling of top players and comps alike, our choice is by no means dead: World number 3 Ding Liren does it pretty much exclusively, Magnus Carlsen used it in his 2016 World Championship match, Levon Aronian always comes back to it after flirting with the Berlin too... We question that b5 bishop, giving us the option to go b5 should it retreat to a4 when we see fit.})

Nowadays that fear is not as present, we have seen enough Berlin endgames by now to know that things are not so simple. Still, Bxc6 is a decent move and I am a bit surprised that it's not more popular than it is @@StartBracket@@outside of Azerbaijan, where it is clearly part of your chess upbringing@@EndBracket@@ . (8.Ne2 {is possible too.}))

Of course, there are some details to consider along the way, but overall this is a simple system and a reliable equalizer, just like Denzel Washington.}

{One of the big plusses of being a Marshall-player and therefore starting with 7...O-O and not 7... d6 is that we can avoid the lines after 7....d6 c3 O-O 8. d4. Of course, we will meet 8. c3 with d5! while attempts to trick us back into it with 8. d4, hoping for d6 9. c3, also gives us a strange alternative. People know this, which is why 8. d4 has become a rare guest at the highest levels. The play in our mainlines is still sharp and far away from any patterns, so I would recommend aspiring Marshall Bravestars to gain a good working knowledge of this line.}
{It is a good idea to recapture that knight.}

{A sad square for the knight for now, but we will work hard for its glorious re-entry into the game via c7, f6 or d6. Meanwhile, White has to decide if he wants to recapture the pawn or sacrifice one.}

{A big reason that this line is out of fashion is this move, which is considered to give Black an edge by Stockfish 10. Black does not want the extra pawn, but returns it instantly, aiming to grab space on the queenside and in the center in return.}
(11...dxc3 {Grabbing the pawn works, for all I know. White gets full compensation and an easier to play position in return, but no more.} 12.Nxc3 d6 {with many options.})
{That was the plan ! We close the position, building a nice pawn chain.}

{Closing it further. Such structures can be very double-edged. If White ever gets f4-f5, we can easily be toast. Therefore a common strategy is to meet f4 with f5 or just to go f5 with Black anyway, claiming a stake on the kingside as well. Of course that gives White a protected and passed e-pawn, but that e-pawn will hardly queen in the middlegame and can safely be blocked by a bishop or a knight from e6. Once the kingside is secured, we can focus on further expanding on the other flank, b4, a5 etc.}
{Threatening Nxd5, so we should not be overzealous with the b-pawn just yet.}

{A fine multipurpose move, parrying the threat of Nxd5 while eyeing the e6 and b5 squares. White faces a choice of how to proceed but his position isn't pretty.}
(14...b4?? 15.Nxd5 Qxd5 16.Be4 {would be bad news.})
{This is Black's dream, the pawn on f4 only restricts his own bishop and knight.}

{The Bishop's Game. This move mainly exists as a device to avoid the Petroff, used by white players that are fine going for the Italian, but not the lines after 2. Nf3 Nf6. As we are 2... Nc6 guys here and willing to enter the Italian anyway, 2. Bc4 is not that big a deal for us and we will just blatantly offer transpositions. There are some independent lines, however, which we should take a look at.}
{An obvious enough start - developing with tempo and attacking the pawn.}

Jan has lots of commentary here about other lines at this point: @@LinkStart@@https://www.chessable.com/variation/5174516/@@LinkEnd@@}

(7.Bb5 Bd6)

{After 4.Nf3, we have reached a key position. It's Black's move, and there is an unbelievable range of options to choose from. It's remarkable how many fully viable lines Black can play. This abundance of possibilities makes it difficult for White to be adequately prepared, as they have to consider so many options.

When I started constructing this repertoire, one goal of mine was to include this position. Being able to play into it as Black gives you enormous flexibility for a long time. You can play the system I recommend, but you'll have tons of alternatives if ever desired.

Alright, what do I recommend for Black now? It is the move 4...a6!?, which is probably not the first move you thought of. Black's is playing a small flank pawn move; isn't there something more pressing to do? Well, I see the point, but hang on! In the notes to 4...a6, I'll make my case why I think it is an excellent choice. Before we put the move on the board, I'll quickly want to give you an overview of possible alternatives that you may consider at a later stage, with a brief description.

Most of the lines are covered on Chessable or might be in the future. Now let's check why I like the move 4...a6.}

{Constructing a complete repertoire for Black usually works like this: you know that you like certain lines and ideas, and then you construct the rest around these cornerstones. In the case of this course, I knew straight away that I wanted to include the main crossroads position after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 and that ~~4...a6## would be my pick. Why? I became aware of the move while watching Magnus Carlsen playing online Blitz/Rapid games. Magnus has played the line often, with great success. In my database, he scored seven wins and nine draws with Black - zero losses! That caught people's attention, and many players followed suit. The line has gained in popularity and has been employed successfully by many strong players.

But now, let's talk about what the little pawn move does. Clearly, it does not contribute to development, but it rather serves a more concrete purpose: we are enforcing the idea to take the c4-pawn and supporting it with the move ...b5. This comes into play after the natural move 4...a6 5.Bg5 dxc4! , when 6.e3 b5 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/6B1/2pP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R2QKB1R w KQkq - 0 6@@EndFEN@@ 6.e4 b5 demonstrate our idea. In these lines, White is already fighting for equality! Let's have an overview of White's possible replies worth checking.

A@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.e3 - A conservative move that covers the c-pawn, but it's rather passive. I suggest answering it with ~~5...Nbd7## . This transposes to the line @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.e3 a6 5.Nc3 Nbd7 , which is examined in the Queen's Gambit Sidelines Chapter.

B@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg5 and @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bf4 fail to react to our threat of taking c4! We grab the pawn, starting fun complications. In those lines, it's often White instead of Black who needs to be careful.

C@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.c5 seeks to gain space on the queenside. As usual, we attack this advanced pawn with ~~5...b6## . This line is interesting, but Black is holding their own nicely.

D@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/1pp2ppp/p3pn2/3p4/2PP4/2N2N2/PP2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.cxd5 exd5 leads to a Carlsbad structure and is White's most popular and likely best move.

This overview already hints at why I like the 4...a6 variation. Line A is harmless, B scores heavily for Black and is fun to play, C is fine for Black and does not require much effort to learn. Finally, line D leads to the Carlsbad structure, a pawn formation that is a cornerstone of our repertoire anyway, as we can reach it in various versions.

This part of the current chapter will have some comparisons and references to the Carlsbad chapter @@StartBracket@@'We have reached a position similar to X' or a 'favourable version of Y'@@EndBracket@@. I, therefore, recommend that you have had a look at the Carlsbad chapter before studying line D, as it makes it easier to understand.

The move 4...a6 will often come as a surprise for White, mainly if you play at the club level or compete in online speed chess. For titled players or Pros, the move 4...a6 has become a mainline in recent years, and White will know how to meet it. At lower levels, you'll have a massive knowledge gap: you know the course contents presented here, while White often won't know a thing!}

{A very natural move and a very common reply to other 4th moves by Black. Here are some examples:

@@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 Be7 5.Bg5

@@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 Nbd7 5.Bg5

@@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 c6 5.Bg5

Often, White players might not appreciate that 4...a6 is precisely directed against 5.Bg5, and they'll just play the move they would go for in other cases. A great point of our line 4...a6 is that 5.Bg5 is now met with a powerful answer.}

{We grab the pawn and are ready to cover it with ...b5, the point of playing ...a6 that early. After 5...dxc4 White needs to be careful to avoid serious trouble, as many natural-looking continuations are dubious. One example is the line}
(5...dxc4! 6.e4 b5 7.e5 {, which might easily net us a quick win if White is not careful. After the capture, White has mostly tried the moves 6.a4, 6.e4 and 6.e3. Let's have a look.})
{Clearly less testing than 6.e4. Our response remains the same: cover the pawn with ...b5!}

{White needs to get some concrete play on the road and attacks our b5-pawn. Against slow moves, we develop @@StartBracket@@...Bb7, ...Nbd7 and ultimately ...c5@@EndBracket@@ and are much better. Instead of 7.a4, White could also play}
(7.Bxf6 {, which we answer with} 7...gxf6! {The doubled pawn is no weakness and helps to cover the important e5-square. We also need the queen in the centre and on the queenside. Throughout the next moves, White may always insert Bxf6, which we always answer with ...gxf6!})
{At first, you'd think that White now can take twice on b5, as there is a pin on the a-file. Well, we have a cunning idea prepared against this...}
{Now we'll check 9.Nxb5 and 9.Bxf6 - both will be answered with a powerful exchange sacrifice.}

{We always take with the pawn. Here}
(9...Qxf6?? {is particularly off due to} 10.Nxb5 {, when we can't sacrifice the exchange and are more or less lost.})
{That's the big point of our concept. We give up the exchange in return for a powerful initiative.}

{Starting with}
(11...Bb7 {and ...Bb4+ next is just as good and transposes.})
{Black has great compensation for the exchange. It's tough to play White's position, as the knight is stuck in an annoying pin and Black's bishops are monsters.}
{Sielecki doesn't mention this one. Gets played more often than Qh5, and doesn't lose on the spot. Black is still in good shape.}
{Clear engine favorite, most played, and scores well.}

(16...Qe7 {keeps a small advantage for black})
(16...Kf8 17.Rd1 Na5 18.Qxd4 Qxd4 19.exd4 Nb3 {and things are a bit hairy but engine still likes Black})

{I have a hard time believing in moving a pawn one square like 1... e6, 1... c6, 1... g6, etc. The center is there, fight for it !

Don't overdo it with something crazy like 1... d5 or 1... Nf6, of course. Now that I've made some friends, let me give you my list of good black openings against 1. e4 to make some more: @@ul@@ @@li@@ The Berlin @@/li@@ @@li@@ The Marshall @@/li@@ @@li@@ The Petroff @@/li@@ @@li@@ The Sveshnikov @@/li@@ @@li@@ The Najdorf @@/li@@ @@li@@ The Open Spanish@@/li@@ @@/ul@@ I'm very curious at what point in the future that list will look completely outdated. If you feel it looks insane already and would like to write a strongly worded letter in defense of the Breyer, the Zaitsev, The Kalashnikov, the Taimanov or the Dragon, please send your complaints to MrDodgyatchessable.com.

Now sometimes, these 'good openings' will not be your best option to play for a win. Fighting for the center, especially with black, will often mean early confrontation there that can lead to either simplification or forced lines making it harder for your opponents to make mistakes. The art of tolerating a slightly worse position after e.g. 1... g6 in order to improve our average score in that game has never been a specialty of mine. One could argue that even if playing one of my 'good openings' is not always the mathematically best choice but spending time learning and playing them will build sound chess habits that will make us stronger chess players.

For me, discovering 1... e5 and giving up the openings of my youth like the Taimanov and the Modern was eye-opening, life seemed so much easier ! Sold ? Ok, let's memorize some draws ! @@StartBracket@@Kidding - kind of.@@EndBracket@@}

{The Scotch. Instead of the slow battles White seeks in the Spanish or Italian, in the Scotch, White immediately changes the situation in the center, forcing the exchange of his d-pawn for the black e-pawn. That will give White greater center control @@StartBracket@@the pawn on e4 versus the pawn on d7@@EndBracket@@ , but there is a price to pay: White is no longer the side with a lead in development, as he will move his knight twice in the first four moves. In many ways, that determines the battles to come: White wants to consolidate his better structure/spacial advantage, while Black should try to play dynamically, developing quickly and asking questions. From an opening theory standpoint, the Scotch is far less scary than the Spanish or the Italian. It still pops up in top-level chess, but mostly as a surprise weapon @@StartBracket@@just like Kasparov undusted it in 1990 to spring it on Karpov@@EndBracket@@ . Black is fine, but especially in the @@StartBracket@@critical@@EndBracket@@ lines I will be recommending. The positions are far from typical, the pawn structure, in particular, being nothing that we are used to. Therefore, it pays off to check it out a bit, as play is often quite tactical/move by move, so relying on common sense and pattern recognition is sometimes not as helpful here.}
{The only decent move.}
{White just recaptures the pawn.}

{This move has been my weapon of choice for a long time now. Black develops the knight and attacks the pawn on e4, what could be more natural ?}
(4...Bc5 {@@StartBracket@@is the main alternative, attacking d4, not e4. As far as I know, it has a good theoretical reputation as well, but I like it less than Nf6, also because it gives White quite a choice: Nxc6, Nb3, and Be3 are all mainline moves, leading to very different types of positions.@@EndBracket@@} 5.Be3
(5.Nb3 Bb6 6.Nc3)
(5.Nxc6 Qf6 6.Qf3) Qf6 6.c3 Nge7)
(4...Qf6 5.Nb3)

{The knight moves for the third time, exchanging his colleague while doubling the black pawns. White could still chicken out from the sharp battles that often follow by going 5. Nc3, transposing back to the much calmer Four Knights.}

{This is not a tough decision as the alternative dxc6 just leads to a thankless endgame with a bad structure.}
(5...dxc6 6.Qxd8 Kxd8 7.Nc3 {is just sad.})

{A critical, but also risky move. White tries to push the knight around, but Black has other ideas. 6. e5 also marks the point of no return, now the game will get properly strange. In Nc3 or Bd3, White still had calmer options.}

{Pinning the pawn. This move looks awkward, but it also forces White into an awkward reply. Black will argue that Qe2 is more hurtful for White than Qe7 is for him.}
(6...Nd5 7.c4 {is just pleasant for White.})
{As forced as Qe7.}

{The knight was under attack and very much has to move. Black wants to follow up with g6-Bg7 more often than not, developing his bishop while attacking the pawn on e5. One key question Black has to answer is how he wants to react to 8. c4, intending to chase his knight around further.}

{This push has attracted players such as Morozevich, Nepomniachtchi, Nakamura, and Caruana. I struggle to explain it - White does not really threaten anything. he creates the options of going Bg5, maybe Rh3, maybe h4-h5. Black has at least 4-5 decent replies. Maybe that is the appeal ? Confuse them with too big a choice ? Anyway, I chose a move. I used the usual method - check what Kramnik played, copy it !}

{Vladdy's latest. Kramnik's note: Don't call me Vladdy. The queen clears the way for the bishop and keeps options open, meeting the vagueness of h4 with the vagueness of Qe6! White has a wide range of moves in reply too - it's hard to exhaust these positions as both sides have so many options. That's probably why it appeals to these creative guys - it's hard to believe it's based on the objective merits of h4...}
(8...a5 9.c4)
{Grabbing space on the queenside, Bb4 + O-O are coming, with an improved version of positions we've already seen.}

{White's most popular and important alternative to the Queen's Gambit is the London System. In the London, White usually doesn't play a quick pawn push c2-c4 to attack our d5-pawn; they develop their pieces first and focus on controlling the e5-square.

Often White will almost automatically follow Bf4 with the moves e3, Nf3, Nbd2, Bd3 and c3, in various move orders. Due to this rather schematic approach, the London 'enjoys' the reputation of being a dull and unambitious opening: 'It's always the same, how boring!'

Well, if it's so dull, why do strong players like the World Champion, Magnus Carlsen, play it quite often? As it is with many openings, it all depends on mindset and intention. If you want to play boring Chess, the London is certainly a good way to start - it has its reputation for a reason.

However, playing the London ambitiously and aggressively is possible; don't fall into the trap of believing your opponent is playing Bf4 to bore you to death. They might only wait for the moment to play Nf3-e5 and rush their kingside pawns up the board, just to mention one not-so-boring idea they might have in mind. How do we fight the London System? White's key idea in the London is the control of the central square e5. I suggest to develop with ...Nf6 and quickly challenge White's bishop with ...e6 and ...Bd6. In most cases, we'll play ...O-O, ...c5, ...Qc7 and ...Nbd7 to increase our influence on e5. It is often possible to accomplish the move ...e6-e5, opening up our c8-bishop. Let's have a quick look at what we are aiming for:

@@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 Nf6 3.e3 e6 4.Nf3 Bd6 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nbd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Bd3 Nbd7 is a widespread sequence and the mainline of the current chapter. We are ready to play ...e6-e5, which gives us equal chances and a comfortable game. White has other options along the way, but this is our 'standard' plan against the London.

Let's talk about move orders. I cover all London lines via the move order @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 , but White has other possible move orders. There is the very popular @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.Bf4 @@StartBracket@@covered via @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 Nf6 3.Nf3 @@EndBracket@@ and finally the rare @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.c3 e6 4.Bf4 @@StartBracket@@covered briefly via ~~1.d4## ~~d5## ~~2.Bf4## ~~Nf6## ~~3.Nf3## ~~e6## ~~4.c3## @@EndBracket@@.

In almost all cases, the different move orders lead to exactly the same positions, but there are some nuances we will discuss.

Before we start, I'd like to mention that Black has many satisfactory replies against the London. I had never seriously studied any theory against it, so I didn't immediately know what to recommend. While doing the initial research for the Caro-Kann part of this course, I learned to appreciate the opening play of German GM Rasmus Svane. I liked the positions he was aiming for and decided it is worth checking what he is playing against other openings.

The setup that I am suggesting against the London is Svane's choice. He has played it numerous times, in particular in online games. Later I discovered that GM Michael Prusikin recommends the same general approach in his excellent book based on the Queen's Gambit for Black. Alright, London Calling!}

{A natural development move.

Now, most of the time, White plays 3.e3, but we will also examine 3.Nf3, as this particular position frequently arises from @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.Bf4 . It will almost always transpose to 3.e3, as White's moves e3 and Nf3 are both very natural and obvious.

Still, one interesting line can only arise via the 3.Nf3 move order: @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 Nf6 3.Nf3 e6 4.Nbd2 . This is relevant to our 'standard setup', as it won't work as well in this case. It is nothing to worry about, just a nuance to be aware of. There are other moves besides 3.e3 and 3.Nf3, but they are harmless or purely transpositional at best.

A@@EndBracket@@ White can play @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp1pppp/5n2/3p4/3P1B2/8/PPP1PPPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 2 3@@EndFEN@@ 3.Nc3 , which we cover via the far more common @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/ppp1pppp/8/3p4/3P4/8/PPP1PPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 2@@EndFEN@@ 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.Bf4 .

B@@EndBracket@@ The moves @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp1pppp/5n2/3p4/3P1B2/8/PPP1PPPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 2 3@@EndFEN@@ 3.c3 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp1pppp/5n2/3p4/3P1B2/8/PPP1PPPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 2 3@@EndFEN@@ 3.h3 are slow and can be answered with our standard plan of ...e6 and ...Bd6.

C@@EndBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp1pppp/5n2/3p4/3P1B2/8/PPP1PPPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 2 3@@EndFEN@@ 3.c4?! is a dubious and rare attempt to play a delayed Queen's Gambit. You can even play ~~3...dxc4## and keep the pawn with ...b5. White's bishop is entirely misplaced on f4 and often later hit with ...Nd5.}

{We prepare ...Bd6, challenging the London bishop. Now organising the material is not easy, as White has about a million different move orders. However, we can split the lines into two sections.

A@@EndBracket@@ White plays a quick Nf3, usually right now on move four

B@@EndBracket@@ White delays/omits the move Nf3, often trying to use the f-pawn after the f4-bishop has moved/has been traded.

If White is going for B, they usually start with 4.Nd2, but you also meet 4.Bd3 or 4.c3 with similar intentions. We don't need to worry about these move orders, as we'll play ...Bd6, ...O-O and ...c5, basically on 'auto pilot'. Lines like @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/3p4/3P1B2/4P3/PPP2PPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 0 4@@EndFEN@@ 4.Bd3 Bd6 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nd2 c5 @@StartBracket@@covered via @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/3p4/3P1B2/4P3/PPP2PPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 0 4@@EndFEN@@ 4.Nd2 Bd6 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Bd3 c5 @@EndBracket@@ or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/3p4/3P1B2/4P3/PPP2PPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 0 4@@EndFEN@@ 4.c3 Bd6 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nd2 c5 7.Ngf3 Qc7 @@StartBracket@@covered via @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/3p4/3P1B2/4P3/PPP2PPP/RN1QKBNR w KQkq - 0 4@@EndFEN@@ 4.Nf3 Bd6 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nbd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 @@EndBracket@@ are purely transpositional.}

{White plays the knight to its best square, which is unsurprisingly the most popular way to play. We'll also reach this position frequently via other moves orders, particularly @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.Bf4 e6 4.e3 is very common. We already know our reply: challenge the London bishop with ...Bd6.}

{According to our plan. White has a whole range of options now. They need to decide what to do about the bishop vis-a-vis. Let's make an overview of the various ideas.

A@@EndBracket@@ The main move is 5.Bg3. White retreats the bishop and argues that Black doesn't want to trade on g3, as this capture opens the h-file now. Against @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg3 , we continue with our standard plan of ~~5...O-O## and ...c5 next.

B@@EndBracket@@ White can continue with moves like @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Nbd2 , @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bd3 or @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.c3 and allow us to capture the bishop on f4. I suggest declining this invitation for the moment and continuing with our usual approach of playing ...O-O and ...c5 first. The three moves mentioned usually lead to the same positions. Therefore I decided to cover White's 'double f-pawn invitation' idea only via 5.Nbd2 and mention the possible alternative routes in the notes to this move. We'd play in the same way against all three, so it's easy to remember.

C@@EndBracket@@ White can play @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Ne5 , occupying their outpost immediately. We'll fight for control over e5 with the moves ...c5, ...Qc7 and ...Nc6.

D@@EndBracket@@ White can simply trade on d6. This move is rather toothless and answered by ~~5.Bxd6## ~~Qxd6## .}
{White immediately occupies their outpost square and avoids a bishop trade. Our usual approach is playing 5...O-O and 6...c5 'against everything'... and it works well here, too.}

{White may also start with}
(6.Bd3 {, when} 6...c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Nd2 Nc6 {transposes to @@StartFEN@@rnbq1rk1/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3pN3/3P1B2/4P3/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQ - 4 6@@EndFEN@@ 6.Nd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Bd3 Nc6 , which we are about to examine in a moment.})
{We are fighting for control of the e5-square.}

{White's main move and probably best. After}
(8.Bg3 Nc6 {we have transposed to @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nbd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Ne5 , while @@StartFEN@@rnb2rk1/ppq2ppp/3bpn2/2ppN3/3P1B2/2P1P3/PP1N1PPP/R2QKB1R w KQ - 1 8@@EndFEN@@ 8.Ndf3? is a real mistake due to ~~8...Ne4!## , when the idea ...c5-c4, followed by f7-f6, is very awkward for White.})

{In the variation @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nbd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Bd3 we need to play ~~8...Nbd7## , because ~~8...Nc6?## fails to ~~9.dxc5## . When given a choice, I prefer the more active ...Nc6. We play in the same way after @@StartFEN@@rnbqk2r/ppp2ppp/3bpn2/3p4/3P1B2/4PN2/PPP2PPP/RN1QKB1R w KQkq - 2 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Bg3 O-O 6.Nbd2 c5 7.c3 Qc7 8.Ne5 Nc6 , which leads to the rule of thumb that ...Nc6 answers Ne5 jumps adequately.}

{The point of the capture will become clearer after 10. exd4 Ne4, when ...f6 is the idea. As mentioned, Black has some good moves here, but it's good to know that the strategically logical move}

It was fun to see that both the 7th World Champion, Mikhail Botvinnik and a possible future World Champion, Alireza Firouzja, had played into this position, 95 years apart!}
{Sielecki doesn't cover this most popular pleb move.}

{This time around, we shall investigate the old mainline where White goes Bb3 at some point, usually to safeguard his bishop from being captured by Na5. As is typical for the Italian, it is one living hell of move-orders and I will not list every single transposition. White will go c3, O-O, Bb3, Nbd2, Re1 and usually h3 followed by Nf1 in some order, while as Black we shall go, a6, d6, Ba7, O-O and then usually h6, Re8, and Be6. Generally the old mainline has fallen a little out of favor, as a2-a4 plans have taken the limelight. It is still pretty popular though, so it does deserve a close look.}
