Now that I've made some friends, let me give you my list of good black openings against 1. e4 to make some more: @@ul@@ @@li@@The Berlin @@li@@The Marshall @@li@@The Petroff @@li@@The Sveshnikov @@li@@The Najdorf @@li@@The Open Spanish@@/ul@@ I'm very curious at what point in the future that list will look completely outdated. If you feel it looks insane already and would like to write a strongly worded letter in defense of the Breyer, the Zaitsev, The Kalashnikov, the Taimanov or the Dragon, please send your complaints to MrDodgyatchessable.com.

Now sometimes, these 'good openings' will not be your best option to play for a win. Fighting for the center, especially with black, will often mean early confrontation there that can lead to either simplification or forced lines making it harder for your opponents to make mistakes. The art of tolerating a slightly worse position after e.g. 1... g6 in order to improve our average score in that game has never been a specialty of mine. One could argue that even if playing one of my 'good openings' is not always the mathematically best choice but spending time learning and playing them will build sound chess habits that will make us stronger chess players.

For me, discovering 1... e5 and giving up the openings of my youth like the Taimanov and the Modern was eye-opening, life seemed so much easier ! Sold ? Ok, let's memorize some draws ! @@StartBracket@@Kidding - kind of.@@EndBracket@@}

{The Ponziani. Not the most popular opening, and for good reason. Of course, White has nothing but the best intentions - go d4, occupy the center and all that. But it's not going to happen, Black will of course accept the invitation to attack the e4-pawn in return, as White has not really used his extra tempo to develop his bishop or attack something. So overall, it's not a very scary line - both Nf6 and d5 equalize. Let's choose one !}
{Surprisingly the critical move. White threatens Nxe5, forcing Black to make a small concession or to give up a pawn. Not today !}
{Just covering our boy on e5. If you want to go Qd6, Nf6 or Bd7 instead, I'm cool with that as well - it's all fine.}
{The best move - White slows things down and makes sure he will get his pieces out, in Philidor-style, Nbd2, Be2, O-O, etc. Black has absolutely no reason to be concerned.}
{f6 is taken, so this is the way.}

{Black has a wide choice here. Comps like a combination of g5, Qd7 and often a6 - especially as a reply to b4, which unfortunately convinced me that the aesthetically pleasing maneuver of Nc8-Nb6 is probably not the way to go. The one thing Black should always keep an eye on is whether d3-d4 is a threat. As long as the answer is no, there is not much to worry about.}

{We might as well start with this, putting g5-g4 on the agenda. As a bonus, it also gives us the option to go Bg7 and O-O.}
(7...Nc8 8.b4 Nb6 9.Qc2 {and the horses on b6 and c6 are a bit vulnerable to a4 followed by a5 or b5 @@StartBracket@@- the black setup is just not that harmonious here.@@EndBracket@@})
(7...Qd7 8.Nbd2
(8.b4 a6) Ng6 9.d4 {is not the end of the world, but it might explain why we go} 9...g5 {- it is nice to counter d4 with g4 , pushing the knight around.})
({SC: Plebs typically play} 8.Nbd2 {here, which JG has lines for. Also popular but not engine-approved is}) (8.b4 {, to which we reply} 8...a6)
(8...Bg7!? 9.Nbd2 O-O {with a complex fight ahead.})
{This is just asking for trouble.}

{How to answer @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4? If you have the Queens's Gambit Declined in your repertoire, there is an easy solution. You play ~~1...e6## and 2...d5, asking White if they have anything better than playing d2-d4 and transposing to a traditional Queen's Gambit or a Catalan. A very common transposition is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nc3 d5 , when ~~3.d4## leads to the mainline Queen's Gambit.

If White wants to avoid this kind of transposition, they have two basic ways to do that. In the current chapter, we will examine g3-based setups, while in the second chapter on ~~1.c4## ~~e6## , we focus on other setups, mostly involving an early e3 by White.

Alright, how do we fight the g3-setups? White's opening bears some similarities to a Catalan @@StartBracket@@ @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nf3 Nf6 4.g3 @@EndBracket@@, and in some cases, it is possible to transpose to this opening quickly. Our approach against the combination of c4 + g3, often called the 'Neo-Catalan' by the way, is quite similar to our Anti-Catalan concept: quickly taking on c4 and then staking a claim in the centre with ...c5, while White is still busy regaining the c-pawn.

The line that arises most of the time and shows the basic concept is @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.g3 Nf6 4.Bg2 dxc4 , when White's primary try is ~~5.Qa4+## ~~Bd7## ~~6.Qxc4## ~~c5## . I think that Black has equal chances in this line and not much to worry about. But what could happen along the way? There are mostly two different scenarios:

1@@EndBracket@@ White can play d4 and transpose into a regular Catalan, for example, after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.g3 Nf6 4.d4 or the less common @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.g3 d5 3.d4 . In both cases, we'd answer with ...dxc4, which is our weapon against the Catalan.

2@@EndBracket@@ The second scenario is quite different: White could play an early b3 to cover the c-pawn. Possible sequences are @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.b3 or ~~1.c4## ~~e6## ~~2.Nf3## ~~d5## ~~3.g3## ~~Nf6## ~~4.b3## . In all these cases, I recommend playing ...d4 in response, gaining central space. We argue that the move b3 is rather pointless when a black pawn appears on d4, as Bb2 is not attractive anymore - staring at an enemy pawn on d4 is not what the bishop wants to do.

Therefore we have a fairly straightforward move order concept: Against g3-setups, we'll play 1...e6, 2...d5, 3...Nf6 and capture on c4 next, unless White plays b3 along the way, when we will advance the d-pawn immediately in response.

An interesting case is the move order ~~1.c4## ~~e6## ~~2.Nf3## ~~d5## ~~3.b3## . White plays b3 even before g3 is on the board. In this case, playing ~~3...d4## is a good option, too. White will very likely continue with g3 soon, which is why this particular move order is also covered in the current chapter.}

{problem block; see source variation
After 2...d5 White can transpose out of this chapter by playing
(2...d5 3.d4 for a Queen's Gambit, or opt for)
(3...e3 , which we cover in the other dedicated chapter on 1.c4 e6.

Our main topic in the current chapter is the move)
(3...g3 , but we'll also examine)
(3...cxd5 3.exd5 g3 and 3.b3 , as after our reply 3...d4! White will almost always play with a quick g3 after all - the immediate 4.g3 is the most popular move.) }

{If White does not want to fianchetto the bishop,}
(3.e3 {is the main alternative to avoid a direct QGD transposition. This possibility is examined in the dedicated chapter @@LinkStart@@https://www.chessable.com/course/92793/18@@LinkEnd@@  on 1.c4 e6 that focuses on setups without g3.})

{I suggest playing 3...Nf6 first. This is consistent with our approach against @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.g3 d5 3.Bg2 when ~~3...Nf6## is the most precise move to reach our preferred lines.

Here, after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.g3 taking on c4 immediately would also be fine to reach our desired lines, but there is no advantage in doing it right away. To keep it consistent, just remember to play ...Nf6 first and take the c-pawn on move four. If you compare with the Catalan and many Queen's Gambit lines, you'll see that we'll usually take on move four, after ...d5, ...e6 and ...Nf6 are already played.}

{White's most natural popular move. There are some transpositional alternatives, though.

A@@EndBracket@@ After} (4.d4 dxc4 {, we'd transpose to a mainline Catalan, covered in a separate chapter @@LinkStart@@https://www.chessable.com/course/92793/14@@LinkEnd@@ . B@@EndBracket@@ White has}) (4.b3 {, which is answered by} 4...d4 {. It will transpose to lines that we cover in the current chapter via the move order @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.b3 d4! . A common and sensible way to transpose is ~~4.b3## ~~d4## ~~5.Bg2## ~~c5## ~~6.e3## ~~Nc6## ~~7.exd4## ~~cxd4## , which gives Black equal chances @@StartBracket@@at least@@EndBracket@@. C@@EndBracket@@ An uncommon way to play is}) (4.cxd5 exd5 {, leading to a structure/position that we cover via @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.cxd5 exd5 4.g3 Nf6 .})

{problem block; see source variation
Similar to a Catalan, we take on c4 and argue that White needs to spend time to regain the pawn. A good alternative for Black is
(4...d4 , which gains space. There are obvious similarities to @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.b3 d4 , which is part of our repertoire and examined in the current chapter.

However, pushing the d-pawn is particularly attractive after White has already played the move b3, which is a slow setup in the Reversed Benoni structure. Here, after @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.c4 e6 2.Nf3 d5 3.g3 Nf6 4.Bg2 d4 , this is not the case. White will find a better way to spend a tempo than b3, which is still not enough to give White a pull. Still, I feel this version of the Reversed Benoni is trickier for Black to handle than my recommended line 4...dxc4 , which is more in spirit with the rest of the repertoire. After)
(4...dxc4 , we will check some moves that White may play. The most popular choice is 5.Qa4+ , which quickly regains the pawn with the queen. The queen loses some time in the process, which gives us time to gain a foothold in the centre.

White has also tried various versions of Na3 to get c4 back, but Black is in fine shape everywhere. Before we get to concrete variations, let's discuss some pointers that help to navigate the various tries that White has.

A@@EndBracket@@ They can play an early queen move.)
(5...Qa4+ is the most common, but)
(5...Qc2 and)
(5...O-O and Qc2 next is played, too. Against all these, we go for a setup based on ...c5 and, if allowed, ...Nc6. We aim to control the d4-square and prevent White from advancing d2-d4. The pointer is that White's queen moves away from supporting d2-d4. Thus we get the chance to play against, and often completely prevent, this idea. B@@EndBracket@@ Against an early Ne5 jump, the answer ...Qd4! is strong if White can't immediately answer with Ne5xc4. Examples are)
(4...dxc4 5.Ne5 Qd4! and @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2p5/5NP1/PP1PPPBP/RNBQK2R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.O-O a6 6.Ne5 Qd4! , but not @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2p5/5NP1/PP1PPPBP/RNBQK2R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Qc2 c5 6.Ne5 when 6...Qd4? is pointless due to 7.Nxc4 . C@@EndBracket@@ We shouldn't allow Nb1-a3xc4, unless White has played Qc2 already. Allowing the knight capture while the white queen is still on d1 is bad, as the sample line)
(4...dxc4 5.Na3 c5?! 6.Nxc4 Nc6 7.O-O Be7 8.b3 O-O 9.Bb2 demonstrates. We can't prevent d2-d4, which opens up the game in White's favour. Their bishops will be mighty once the centre is cleared of pawns. To compare with scenario A:)
(4...dxc4 5.Qc2 c5 6.Na3 Nc6 7.Nxc4 is fine for Black, as we control d4. However, if White plays @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2p5/5NP1/PP1PPPBP/RNBQK2R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Na3 , the only good move is 5...Bxa3 , stopping Nxc4 in its tracks. After)
(4...dxc4 5.O-O a6 6.Na3 , we also should stop Nxc4, in this case with 6...b5 . Let's check White's various options, move by move.) }

{The move} (5.O-O {is one of the trickier options that White has available. If you remember the three pointers in the notes to 4...dxc4, you'll notice that castling does not tell us if White wants to move their queen next @@StartBracket@@...c5! is our concept@@EndBracket@@ or maybe play Na3, after which we don't want to allow Na3xc4.

Alright, what do we play? Some moves don't fit our concept and are dubious, for example,} 5...c5?! 6.Na3! {or @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2p5/5NP1/PP1PPPBP/RNBQ1RK1 b kq - 1 5@@EndFEN@@ 5...Be7?! 6.Na3! , when we don't want to move the bishop again to capture the knight, being a full tempo down on @@StartFEN@@rnbqkb1r/ppp2ppp/4pn2/8/2p5/5NP1/PP1PPPBP/RNBQK2R w KQkq - 0 5@@EndFEN@@ 5.Na3 Bxa3! . The solution is not apparent but makes perfect sense once you see it and check some moves.})

{A surprisingly effective move. It fits into our framework well, as}
(5...a6! 6.Qc2 c5! {still works well. After})
(5...a6! 6.Na3 {, we have} 6...b5 {to cover the pawn, realising the basic idea of ...a6. After 5...a6,  White's most popular move is})
(5...a6! 6.a4 {, which changes the position considerably and allows an entirely different reply, as we will see.})
{White stops any plans of ...b5, but the move comes at a price tag: it doesn't help development and weakens the queenside. The idea Qa4@@StartBracket@@+@@EndBracket@@ is also off the table.}

{I am using the exclam not because it is a brilliant move, but because it is a bit uncommon in our repertoire to play ...Nc6 with the c-pawn still resting on c7. There are some cases, though, related to the moves ...a6 and a4.

In the Queen's Gambit, we play the following line: @@StartFEN@@rnbqkbnr/pppppppp/8/8/8/8/PPPPPPPP/RNBQKBNR w KQkq - 0 1@@EndFEN@@ 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Nf3 a6 5.Bg5 dxc4 6.a4 Nc6! , which shares some ideas with the current position.

With ...Nc6, we connect with the weak square b4, which applies to both lines. A difference to the QGD line is that White's d-pawn is still on d2, which leads to a second and crucial point of ...Nc6: we prepare ...e5, which gains central space and allows an easy development.}
{This natural move leads to some trouble for White.}
{White is more or less lost in this position, as we will see.}
{That's the issue. We drive away the f3-knight and clear d4 for our knight to jump to.}
{And we are an exchange up and should win easily.}

fields.text: {Our move remains the same irrespective of Black playing Nc6 or Nf6. We want to give threats of Nb5/Bc4, and Black will have to deal with that.}
{Another logical move to target the knight on a3, and a mistake. White takes over now with inspiring play.}
{A nice intermediate move threatening Nc7.}

({The only sensible way to stop ...Nc7+ that does not lose instantly.

} 7...Qd8 {occurred more than 70 times and after} 8.Bf4 {Black cannot stop ...Nc7-ideas, and engines give +5 for White already.})
{A cute move. Black cannot take on c4 due to the Nxd6 fork.}
{A great move! Using the vulnerability of the d6 bishop, White develops his bishop and blocks the check. Black cannot take this bishop either due to the Nxd6 fork.}
{Only way to keep control of the c7/d6-square.}
{There is no rush to take on d4. Let us get as many tempos as possible. The bishop gets to a better diagonal now.}
{Black remains underdeveloped, and his pieces are passively placed, which promises White a great position.}
